awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Fellowship: SPRF: Reconstructing Precontact Caribbean Settlement using Ancient DNA
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of the NSF Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) and Linguistics programs. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Maria Nieves-Colón at the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist analyzing the genetic diversity of early populations. By providing the first ancient DNA data from the earliest known ancestral remains from Puerto Rico and other ancient communities, questions related to the process of population origins, island settlement, and regional interaction will be addressed. An improved characterization of broader human population history in the region is crucial in understanding the biocultural connections between these ancient communities and present-day islanders and diaspora. This project also prioritizes community consultation as a part of the research process and supports education for a diverse group of students by providing training opportunities. 

The process of initial human arrival represents one of the most significant but least understood population movements in the ancient history of the Americas. While archaeological, linguistic, and more recently, genetic research has contributed a wealth of knowledge to our understanding of human settlement and interaction, questions regarding the population origins, dispersal trajectories, and the extent of interaction between communities are still debated. This NSF postdoctoral fellowship applies techniques in ancient DNA to characterize the genetic diversity of precontact communities and time periods that have not yet been studied using this method. These results will be integrated with existing archaeological knowledge to address these lingering questions. Additionally, a primary objective of this work is to prioritize community involvement and build groundwork for ethical paleogenomics research. Through partnerships with local universities, museums, and non-governmental organizations, this project will include consultations to facilitate community input into the research process, share results, and create local student education and training opportunities in biological anthropology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Initial human arrival in the insular Caribbean is one of the most significant, yet least understood population dispersals in the history of the Americas. The dynamics associated with multiple waves of dispersal into the region coupled with the emergence of extensive interaction networks have led to a complex and unique population history. While information from archaeology, linguistics, and more recently, genetics, have contributed a wealth of knowledge surrounding human settlement and interaction in the Caribbean, many issues related to population origins, interactions, and the pathways of past migrations are still debated. In recent years, DNA obtained from ancient humans (ancient DNA, or aDNA), has quickly become a promising method for exploring population dispersals in island systems, however, its application in studying past Caribbean peoples has been relatively limited. 

This project improved the characterization of early Caribbean populations by providing the first aDNA data from ancient communities in the southern Lesser Antilles and the earliest period of settlement (referred to as the “Archaic Age”) in Puerto Rico. In doing so, the project addresses two major research objectives: First, to investigate the genetic ancestry of the first settlers of the island of Puerto Rico, as well as changes in genetic diversity on the island over time; and second, to characterize the role of islands in the southern Caribbean in regional genetic variation and population relationships prior to European contact. Additionally, this project sought to establish foundations for ethical practices in Caribbean aDNA research by prioritizing community partnerships, consultation, and outreach initiatives as major components of the work. 

Through collaboration with international research partners, we sampled 63 ancient individuals from archaeological sites located across the islands of Barbados, Carriacou, and Puerto Rico for aDNA analysis. We generated preliminary screening data for each individual to assess overall DNA preservation, and for those individuals that did possess preserved DNA, we produced additional in-depth data. To provide additional temporal context, we also generated radiocarbon dates for a subset of the analyzed individuals. 

Although DNA preservation was generally poor, which is typical of aDNA in tropical regions, chromosomal sex has been estimated for a subset of individuals. These results are consistent with estimates of sex based on prior skeletal analyses conducted as part of previous research. In the case of four individuals from Carriacou, an estimate of biological sex could not be determined from prior work, and in these cases, the chromosomal estimates are contributing new information about these people.

Preliminary mitochondrial lineage assignments, which reflect maternal ancestry, have also been made. Though tentative, results can confirm that the maternal ancestry of the ancient islanders included in the project are consistent with others living on other islands in the region at this time. Additionally, and importantly, these lineages have also been identified in contemporary communities across the region, further confirming that there are enduring connections between ancient and contemporary islanders today and illustrating the need for involving descendant communities in aDNA research.

By providing the first aDNA data from ancient communities in the southern Lesser Antilles and the Archaic Age in Puerto Rico, this work is expanding our understanding of the archaeology, history, and evolution of Caribbean populations. Broadly, these data also help to clarify connections between precontact communities and present-day islanders, which is of particular interest to island and diasporic Caribbean people. Characterizing ancestry and regional genetic diversity provides important foundations for research in human genomics and evolutionary medicine. Therefore, adding a new dimension to this work by contributing a deeper time perspective to our understanding of genetic diversity and demographic history in a region commonly underrepresented in human genomics has the potential to better inform future research. 

The data collection and analyses involved in the study were part of the postdoctoral training of the principal investigator. Additionally, this project has made broader contributions to local, national, and global communities. Undergraduate and graduate students in the United States and Puerto Rico received training in genetics laboratory and data analysis methods, bioarchaeological field methods, and mentorship related to various aspects of professional development, including applying to and attending graduate school and career options in anthropology and the biological sciences. Overall research results are currently being prepared for peer-review and project findings are being actively disseminated through presentations at international scientific meetings and regular project updates with local partners in Barbados, Grenada, and Puerto Rico. Lastly, data access agreements are being created with local partners to ensure that future use of the data generated as part of this project by other researchers is done so in compliance with the consent provided by existing permissions. If congruent with community interests, the sequence data will be made freely available upon completion.
